author: Paul Page
title: Today’s Top Supply Chain and Logistics News From - WSJ
text:

Industrial supply chains in the U.S. are starting to heat up in anticipation of new tariffs on imported steel and aluminum. United States Steel Corp. X -2.93% says it will fire up a blast furnace in Granite City, Ill., and call back 500 workers, while Century Aluminum Co. CENX -7.48% is preparing to restart lines at a smelter in Kentucky that have been curtailed since 2015 . The WSJ’s Bob Tita and Andrew Tangel write steel and aluminum makers are ramping up capacity to make up for imports that may become too expensive for American manufacturers. President Donald Trump is expected to sign his proclamation outlining the new tariffs today, even as many congressional Republicans continue to object to the plan and exporters are raising concerns over retaliation. The impact on metal markets is already forming, with American producers firing up more furnaces so they don’t lose out to foreign competitors if they can’t make enough metal to meet demand, even at higher prices.
Amazon.com Inc. is stepping up its bid for low-income shoppers as it tries to build more volume in its burgeoning logistics network. The online giant is extending its discounted Prime program to the roughly 20% of the U.S. population that is signed up for Medicaid , the WSJ’s Laura Stevens reports, launching a new salvo in a battle for customers with Walmart Inc. as Amazon looks to build a bigger audience for its marketplace. Analysts say low-income households haven’t moved online as forcefully as wealthier shoppers, but consumer habits are shifting and driving more household staples through Amazon’s system. Most low-income shoppers now have mobile phones, and companies including United Parcel Service Inc. and Amazon have been adding lockers and other pickup locations for safe, more convenient delivery. Amazon is betting that cutting the cost of membership and shipping will push more goods through its distribution centers—and more revenue to the company’s digital services.
The rebound in global metals markets is starting to show some cracks. A rally that had helped boost troubled the commodities business has partly reversed this year, signaling that investor conviction in a rosy economic outlook is giving way to concern over slowing demand and unease that metals have turned into risky assets. The WSJ’s Amrith Ramkumar reports that copper futures have slipped 4.3% this year after reaching a near four-year high in December and that prices for zinc and lead are falling. Global steel and aluminum prices are down, even as U.S. prices for the metals have risen on the back of President Donald Trump’s pledge for new tariffs on imports. The unease could undermine a fragile recovery for bulk carriers that began last year. Bulk shipping prices have been recovering recently from a December-January swoon but research group Alphabulk says freight rates for vessel operators remain below the levels of 2013, however.
SUPPLY CHAIN STRATEGIES The U.S. Steel Corp. Granite City Works facility. Photo: Bloomberg News A highly private European holding company is quietly building a caffeine-fueled global powerhouse. Little-known JAB, a one-time industrial chemicals manufacturer, is emerging from the shadows with a series of acquisitions of big brand consumer names to give the business a sprawling national network to distribute cold-brewed coffees . The WSJ’s Zeke Turner and Julie Jargon report that JAB started its growth push buying Keurig Green Mountain in 2016 for $13.9 billion, and capped a stream of acquisitions this January with the $26 billion buy of Dr Pepper Snapple Group Inc. The driving strategy is to build ever-larger scale to sell coffee in nearly every form and venue, including distribution of brands such as Dunkin’ Donuts and Starbucks that it doesn’t own. JAB is betting the U.S. beverage industry is on the cusp of a reorganization that will favor more disciplined supply-chain management that can come from owning both the brands and the distribution network.
QUOTABLE
‘ They come for shipping. They stay for digital. ’
—Aaron Perrine, head of Amazon’s discounted membership program.
Number of the Day 19.4% Year-over-year increase in U.S. rail shipments of metallic ores in February, according to the Association of American Railroads.
IN OTHER NEWS U.S. imports were flat in January and exports fell 1.3%, leaving the trade deficit at its highest level in over nine years . (WSJ)
China’s exports surged unexpectedly by 44.5% in February, further widening its global trade surplus . (WSJ)
Japan, Canada, Mexico and eight other Pacific nations are set to sign a new version of the Trans-Pacific Partnership today. (WSJ)
A fire raged aboard a Maersk Line vessel for a second day as the shipping line confirmed that one evacuated crew member had died. (WSJ)
Canadian exports and imports fell sharply in January . (WSJ)
Firms across the country added 235,000 workers in February . (WSJ)
U.S. productivity growth stalled at the end of last year while the cost of labor grew more quickly than previously thought. (WSJ)
A Federal Reserve report shows wages and benefits rising across the U.S. this year. (WSJ)
Greg Greeley, the former head of Amazon Prime and one of Amazon’s longest-serving executives , is joining Airbnb Inc. (WSJ)
Coca-Cola Co. plans to introduce a fizzy alcoholic drink in Japan, the first alcoholic product in the company’s history. (WSJ)
Singapore-based Broadcom Ltd. will invest $1.5 billion in the U.S. to ease regulatory concerns over its hostile takeover bid for Qualcomm Inc. (WSJ)
The use of semiconductors in a growing array of products is easing the boom-and-bust cycle for makers of chip manufacturing equipment . (WSJ)
British manufacturers are considering building up stockpiles of goods ahead of potential transport delays after Brexit. (Bloomberg)
Canadian National Railway Co says it will add more than $193 million in spending this year to improve its infrastructure . (Reuters)
Walmart Inc. says operating its own dedicated fleet has minimized the impact of rising transportation costs . (Supermarket News)
Mining giant Rio Tinto PLC is expanding use of autonomous trucks to a fifth mine in Australia. (West Australia News)
Container shipping lines are likely to slow their vessels to help comply with new emissions restrictions . (Lloyd’s List)
Bulk vessels are crowding ports in Western Canada waiting for grain shipments delayed on rail lines . (Globe and Mail)
California’s Merced County wants to use an agreement with the Port of Los Angeles to attract manufacturing and distribution business. (KVPR)
RoadOne Intermoda Logistics acquired New England-based regional transport provider Jarvis Trans Inc. (American Shipper)
